description: From Latin circumferentia, from circum (“around”) + ferō (“I carry”). Displaced native Old English ymbgang.

entries.meaning: (geometry) The line that bounds a circle or other two-dimensional figure
(geometry) The length of such a line
(obsolete) The surface of a round or spherical object
(graph theory) The length of the longest cycle of a graph

verbs.description: circumference (third-person singular simple present circumferences, present participle circumferencing, simple past and past participle circumferenced)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To include in a circular space; to bound.
